comment.author: 25453448@N02
comment._content: River Wye in foreground.  A famous view for British geomorphologists as it shows the development of a river meander as the river progressively undercuts the bank beneath the viewpoint leaving a record of older meander positions behind it.

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: thank you Darkroom Daze for your explanation of this image. We will add the River Wye to the description when we update.

comment.author: 25453448@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/arden_loc] Glad to help. The River Wye in this area shows examples of this and various other classic geomorphological features (e.g. the river is 'incised' and 'superimposed').  The bedrock geology of the Carboniferous (Misissippian) Limetone exposed in the cliffs here, and also seen in other Chepstow postcards posted here, is also of geological interest.  But I assumed more information about these things would be more technical than you would want!

comment.author: 77094997@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/92838396@N02] The Library of Congress didn't take these photos. They are 100 years old! ;-)
